Pilot or feasibility studies are usually not considered to be a specific phase. However, there is consensus that they typically precede a clinical trial and share characteristics with both exploratory research and the intervention development phase. They are used to demonstrate the preliminary effectiveness of an intervention approach and to collect data to design a future clinical trial. The main goal of pilot or feasibility studies is to provide information on whether a study design is sound enough to support conducting a larger, more definitive trial.

Certainly! Let's start with the active comparator for the adaptive phenotypes. This group will consist of the Adaptive-A and Adaptive-B subgroups. Participants will be administered Dupilumab (Dupixent), an interleukin-4 receptor alpha antagonist. They will also be exposed to House Dust Mites (HDM) in the aeroallergen challenge chamber. The goal is to evaluate the efficacy of Dupilumab in individuals with adaptive phenotypes.

The experimental group for maladaptive phenotypes will also be divided into Maladaptive-A and Maladaptive-B subgroups. Participants in this group will receive Dupilumab (Dupixent) and undergo exposure to House Dust Mites (HDM) in the aeroallergen challenge chamber. The purpose is to assess the effectiveness of Dupilumab in individuals with maladaptive phenotypes and compare the treatment response between adaptive and maladaptive phenotypes.

The placebo comparator arms will mirror the adaptive and maladaptive phenotypes. Participants in the Adaptive-A and Adaptive-B subgroups will receive an inert placebo instead of the active drug but will still be exposed to House Dust Mites (HDM) in the aeroallergen challenge chamber. The same applies to the Maladaptive-A and Maladaptive-B subgroups. These arms are important for establishing a baseline response in adaptive and maladaptive phenotypes when not receiving the active drug.

The first arm, called the "Facilitated Group ACP Session," will involve participants attending a one-time 90-minute facilitated group ACP session. During this session, they will review the movie version of the PREPARE program, including a new PSH-specific video and PREPARE easy-to-read advance directives with the new PSH-specific content and cover letters. The group facilitators will adhere to standardized scripts and protocols to engage participants in ACP through group sessions.

The second study arm is called "Facilitated one-on-one ACP visits." Participants in this arm will also attend a one-time 90-minute ACP session, but in a one-on-one setting with a facilitator. They will review the movie version of the PREPARE program, along with the new PSH-specific video and PREPARE easy-to-read advance directives. The facilitator will adhere to scripts and protocols to engage participants in advance care planning, tailoring the session to their unique circumstances.

In order to standardize the gait analysis between visits, we propose conducting the gait analysis protocol at each visit in the following sequence: passive range of motion, sitting, standing up, static posture, and stepping. Each part will be followed by a familiarization session to avoid unexpected muscle contractions while wearing the equipment. The gait analysis protocol will consist of the following components: (I) a 5 m walking trial at self-selected speed in the center of a 10 m walkway, (II) a turn in place on each leg for 15 s, (III) walking at preferred and maximum speeds, and (IV) sitting, standing, and walking repetitions at the rate of one repetition per second. Additionally, we plan on incorporating the following validated scales: 1) the Berg Balance Scale (BBS) to quantify dynamic balance, 2) the modified Ashworth Scale (MAS) to measure spasticity, and 3) the Fugl-Meyer Assessment - Lower Extremity Function (FMA-LE) to measure motor impairment in the lower limbs. Finally, the following inclusion and exclusion criteria will be applied:(Inclusions):-Aged above 40 years old-Chronic stroke that occurred at least six months prior to the inclusion. The diagnosis should have been confirmed on an MRI performed during the hyper acute phase or within the first three months after the acute phase-Unable to walk without assistive devices and/or a human support-Intelligence Quotient above 80-Written informed consent signed-Able to walk from the wheelchair alone-Able to walk at least 30 meters with a human support-FMA-LE score between 0-55-Modified Ashworth Scale score below 3-Berg Balance Scale score below 50(Exclusions):-Psychological impossibility of completing the protocol -Psychomotor disturbances -Lung disease -Severe cardiovascular disease -Severe articular disease --Severe vestibular, peripheral, and ocular diseases --Lower limb amputation --Diagnosis of other neurological diseases -Tumors --Hip prosthesis --Vertebral injury --Parkinson's disease --Hepatic or renal

For the extracorporeal shock wave group, we can assign patients with lateral epicondylitis to this arm. For the ultrasound group, we can also assign patients with lateral epicondylitis. The intervention would be the same physiotherapy program as the extracorporeal shock wave group. Additionally, they would receive ultrasound therapy at 1.5 watt/cm2 in continuous mode to the painful area for 5 minutes, 5 days a week for two weeks. This would be in addition to the ten-day physiotherapy program. How does that sound?

For the dexamethasone iontophoresis group, we can assign patients with lateral epicondylitis. The intervention would be the same physiotherapy program as the other groups. Additionally, they would receive dexamethasone iontophoresis therapy for 10 days. In each session, 0.1% dexamethasone ophthalmic pomade would be applied to the anodal electrode and placed on the lateral epicondyle. Galvanic current would be applied at 0.1-0.2 milliampere/cm2. This would also be in addition to the ten-day physiotherapy program. What do you think?

   - Participant Group/Arm: Patients with lateral epicondylitis who will receive ultrasound therapy.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Patients in this group will undergo the same physiotherapy program as the ESWT group. Additionally, they will receive ultrasound therapy at 1.5 watt/cm2 in continuous mode to the painful area for 5 minutes, 5 days a week for two weeks.

It is designed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of AND017 in the treatment of cancer-related anemia patients receiving chemotherapy. model_response: Got it! An interventional study usually means that the investigator will intentionally apply a specific action or treatment to participants. In contrast, an observational or epidemiological study usually means that investigators observe behaviors without taking any specific action. Understood. Based on your information, your trial seems to be a randomized crossover study. A crossover study, also known as a crossover trial or randomized crossover trial, is a single-blind trial in which each participant receives treatments from each intervention or treatment group in sequence. The advantage of crossover trials is that each participant acts as their own control. As a result, crossover trials generally require fewer participants and less statistical evidence than a parallel group design trial, in this case randomized controlled trial (RCT). However, this comes at the cost of high heterogeneity between each participant as there is no control group. Thus, you may consider using statistical methods such as analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) and analysis of variance (ANOVA) to account for variation between participants .

The design of the experimental arm of the study combines passive heat therapy and thermal biofeedback using a hot tub at 40 degrees Celsius aimed at raising the core body temperature of the study participants to 38.5 degrees Celsius. This type of passive heat therapy has previously been shown beneficial for cardiovascular disease, as it promotes an exercise-like thermal response without the additional cardiovascular response that would be present during physical exercise. By selecting individuals with higher-level spinal cord injuries, the intervention aims to investigate the potential for a larger cardioprotective effect, taking advantage of the potential for increased vagal nerve activity in the absence of the sympathetic influences of physical exercise. The criteria for the participant group also includes a level transfer being possible with minimal assistance to ensure safety during transfers to the hot tub, and a past engagement in regular bowel and bladder management programs to aid comfort during the intervention's thermal biofeedback. Overall, this experimental arm is designed for longer passive heating to investigate larger cardiac responses and for individuals with higher-level spinal cord injury to increase the potential for vagal modulation.

This arm is essential to compare the outcomes of patients undergoing LDP with those undergoing LRAMPS. The LDP procedure involves dissection behind the fusion fascia and the removal of specific lymph nodes based on the tumor location. This arm allows for a comparison of outcomes between LDP and LRAMPS in the context of early-stage left-sided pancreatic cancer.

Yes, randomization is usually the best way to assign participants to treatment arms. Will randomization be at the individual or cluster level? If there are any cluster-specific features, they should be considered in randomization.

A crossover assignment is a useful option for clinical trials where participants serve as their own control and transition back and forth between interventions and non-interventions. However, if you decide to go with a crossover assignment model, you'll need to modify the blinding protocol. In a crossover clinical trial, participants cannot be blinded because they will necessarily know which intervention they are receiving at any specific time point. Therefore, the best option is to randomly assign participants to the different intervention groups in order to avoid any potential biases in the allocation sequence. For example, in your study, you might consider randomly assigning half of the participants to the blueberry intervention group and the other half to the control group. After a set period of time, all of the participants would then transition to the other group and receive the opposite intervention. This would ensure that both groups receive the same treatments, and the results would be the same as if all participants had been assigned to the same group.

Thank you for the details of the trial. It appears that the study is a randomized controlled trial with a pre-post test design. In this design, the participants are randomized into two groups to receive either an intervention or a control condition. The study is a single-group assignment design, with no masking between the study participants. The purpose of the study is prevention. The participants in this trial will be randomized into two groups: the control and intervention conditions. The control condition will receive nothing additional to the standard care provided in the clinic. The intervention condition will receive an additional object, such as a stress ball, during the lumbar puncture procedure. The outcome variable will be the anxiety level of the participants during the procedure. The hypothesis is that the additional object will help to reduce stress and thereby lower the anxiety level during the lumbar puncture procedure. The primary outcome measure is the anxiety level of the participants in each group. The secondary outcome measure is the physical comfort of the participants while undergoing the procedure in each group. The data collection method will involve a survey before and after the procedure. The survey will collect information on anxiety and comfort levels. The data will be analyzed using t-tests to compare the two groups' anxiety levels. The study will take place in a single neurology clinic. The results will provide evidence of whether the additional object helps to reduce anxiety and improve comfort during the lumbar puncture procedure. The research could lead to an evidence-based recommendation to use additional objects for patients to help improve their experience during the procedure.

For the control group, I suggest selecting a group of neurology patients coming for lumbar puncture who will not receive any intervention during the procedure. The primary purpose of this arm is to serve as a baseline for evaluating the effect of the intervention on anxiety levels. Having a control group will help to ensure that any observed changes in anxiety levels in the experimental arm are due to the intervention rather than other factors.

Certainly. For the experimental arm, participants will receive a pre-selected stress ball in the neurology clinic immediately before the start of the procedure. The stress ball will be red to match the theme of neurology. The participants will be asked to hold and squeeze the stress ball at any point during the procedure. We want them to receive the intervention whenever they feel anxious about the procedure, and we want them to be able to adjust and use it based on their comfort.

In the control group, patients will receive all the care that those coming through the emergency room receive. To make it easier to understand, I will use the diagram below (Figure 1). After the lumbar puncture, the physician removes the needle and provides postoperative care.

Thanks. Based on this information, the study is an interventional study, which aims to evaluate the acute and long-term effect of CPAP therapy on OSA symptoms. To qualify for participation in the study, patients must be adults aged 18 or over with a diagnosis of moderate or severe OSA who have not yet received treatment. The diagnosis of OSA is based on the results of an in-laboratory sleep study, which indicates a moderate or higher level of AHI and oxygen desaturation events per hour, an Epworth Sleepiness Scale Score of 7/24 points, and an indication for CPAP therapy. Patients must also provide written informed consent to participate. Patients with moderate or more severe ventilatory disorders or sleep-related breathing disorders, heart failure, or hypoxic or hypercapnic respiratory failure are excluded from participating in the study. In addition, patients who are currently receiving CPAP therapy for OSA, who may have experienced sleepiness-related accidents due to their current occupational status (including professional drivers), or who are pregnant are excluded from participating in the study.

There are several reasons why an ultrasound-guided serratus anterior plane block was chosen for the first study arm. First, rib fractures are responsible for a high portion of acute pain-related admissions to the hospital (Nyholm et al., 2018). Post-surgical pain management is important for these patients to ensure their comfort and improve their recovery. Second, the ultrasound-guided serratus anterior plane block has been shown to be effective in postoperative pain management following chest surgeries (Nyholm et al., 2018; Uezu et al., 2019), which further supports its use for post-surgical pain management. Additionally, the serratus anterior plane block can reduce the need for opioid use and its associated adverse effects (Nyholm et al., 2018; Cheng et al., 2021).

The second study arm is the Test group. In this arm, patients will receive intravenous dexmedetomidine infusion for pain management. They will receive a bolus of 2 mg/kg dexmedetomidine followed by an infusion of 0.7 μg/kg/hr for 48 hours. This arm will be referred to as Group D.

Dexmedetomidine is commonly used in intensive care units to provide sedation and analgesia, and it has been shown to reduce the need for opioids, improve pain control, and reduce opioid-related complications. Given this information, it is a logical second comparator for this study, especially considering that patients in the first arm will receive a combination of levobupivacaine and dexmedetomidine.

For an observational study evaluating the accuracy of a new diagnostic test, the choice of participants is critical. First, consider the target population for which the diagnostic test is intended. In this case, it appears that you are interested in evaluating coronary artery stenosis. Therefore, you will want to focus on individuals who fall into this category.

Patients with significant stenosis (> 90%) detected by coronary computed tomography angiography or coronary angiography, as well as patients with unstable angina, myocardial infarction, uncontrolled high blood pressure, or severe heart failure, should be excluded from the study. Patients with severely calcified vessels (calcified arc) and/or intracoronary thrombus should also be excluded, as should patients with severe valvular heart disease that may require surgical treatment or with a history of congenital heart disease.

Since you're planning to compare the diagnostic accuracy of three diagnostic tests (FFR, UFR, and IVUS), it would be appropriate to have four study arms: (1) invasive gold standard study arm; (2) UFR; (3) IVUS; and (4) FFR.

The second arm of the study should involve the diagnostic test under investigation, ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR), as the participant group. The intervention/treatment in this arm of the study should be the new ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR) diagnostic technique.

groundtruth: Since your study is focused on evaluating the accuracy of a new diagnostic test, I would recommend classifying it as a Phase II study. This phase typically involves testing the efficacy and safety of new interventions or techniques.

For participant inclusion, you could consider stable angina pectoris, unstable angina pectoris, or individuals who have passed the acute phase of myocardial infarction. The age requirement should be set at 18 years or older, and written informed consent is essential. Additionally, participants should have intermediate coronary lesions with diameter stenosis ranging from 30% to 80% as estimated by visual examination from coronary angiography.

Participants should be excluded if they are ineligible for diagnostic IVUS or FFR examination, have undergone prior coronary artery bypass grafting of the interrogated vessels, experienced myocardial infarction within 72 hours of coronary angiography, or have severe heart failure. Serum creatinine levels greater than 150 umol/L or glomerular filtration rates below 45 ml/kg/1.73 m2 should also be considered exclusions. Furthermore, individuals with allergies to the contrast agent or adenosine, life expectancy of less than 2 years, IVUS pullback that does not cover the entire lesion, or severe myocardial bridge in the interrogated vessel should be excluded from the study.

Based on the information you provided, I suggest having two study arms. The first arm will focus on pressure wire-based fractional flow reserve (FFR) as the participant group. The intervention/treatment for this arm should be the diagnostic test: fractional flow reserve (FFR). This arm is necessary as FFR is a well-established standard reference for assessing the functional significance of coronary artery stenosis. By using pressure wire-based FFR as a comparison, we can evaluate the accuracy of the new diagnostic test, ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR).

The second study arm should involve participants who will undergo intravascular ultrasound (IVUS)-based ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR). The intervention/treatment for this arm should be the diagnostic tests: ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR) and intravascular ultrasound (IVUS). This arm is important as it focuses on the new diagnostic test, UFR, which is the main intervention being evaluated in this trial. By combining UFR with IVUS, we aim to assess the functional significance of coronary artery stenosis in a more comprehensive manner. The use of IVUS will provide detailed imaging of the coronary vessels, enhancing the accuracy of UFR calculations.

model_response: The intervention/treatment in this study arm is ICI201 CAR-T cell injection. ICI201 is a chimeric antigen receptor antibody, and CAR refers to chimeric antigen receptor. Antibodies are proteins that can bind to specific targets, and cancer cells have unique characteristics compared to normal cells. Using genetic engineering, T cells can be modified to express a synthetic antibody receptor that specifically targets cancer cells. This process can help the immune system to attack cancer cells more effectively without harming healthy cells. We have chosen CAR-T cell therapy as the treatment since it has shown promising results in treating multiple myeloma. This approach involves injecting engineered T cells into a cancer patient, where they will bind to and attack cancer cells. So far, the evidence on ICI201 in cancer therapy is encouraging and may provide new hope for patients with relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma.

Certainly! CAR-T cell therapy involves the use of T cells that have been genetically modified to express chimeric antigen receptors (CARs). These CARs recognize and bind specific antigens on the surface of cancer cells. ICI201 is a particular type of CAR that recognizes GPRC5D expressed on the surface of multiple myeloma cells.

Moving on to the second study arm, I propose using only 18FDG PET/CT scans for lobular breast carcinoma staging. The objective of this study arm is to provide a point of reference for comparing the results of 68Ga-FAPI-46 PET compared to standard 18F-FDG PET in staging of this challenging breast cancer type. This trial would result in a significant contribution to the PET literature by providing an alternative to 18F-FDG alone for visualization of lobular breast carcinoma. The use of 18F-FDG alone for imaging of tumors is often limited due to uptake patterns, high background activity, heterogeneous uptake, small and flat morphology, and low visibility relative to normal breast tissue. 18F-FDG is not sufficient to fully characterize tumor extent, size, location, and multifocality, which is critical for accurate staging.

Lastly, I propose an additional arm as a control group receiving the 18-FDG PET scan alone for comparison.   - Participant Group/Arm: Subject with a history of SCAD will undergo a series of diagnostic studies to assess neurovascular function.
  - Intervention/Treatment:
    - Arterial Tonometry: Measure arterial stiffness using arterial tonometry.
    - Echocardiogram: Collect limited ultrasound images of the heart.
    - Carotid Ultrasounds: Perform ultrasound imaging of the carotid artery.
    - Elastography: Measure the elastic properties of the arteries using elastography.
    - Ankle-Brachial Index: Measure the ankle-brachial index to assess peripheral artery blood flow.
    - Microneurography with sympathoexcitatory maneuvers: Measure sympathetic nerve activity at rest and in response to isometric handgrip, mental stress test, cold pressor test, Valsalva maneuvers.

  - Participant Group/Arm: Healthy subjects will undergo a series of diagnostic studies to assess neurovascular function.

groundtruth: The control group will receive normal saline via nasal administration. This will serve as the placebo comparator to evaluate the specific effects of Dexmedetomidine and Esketamine on improving sleep quality. By comparing the outcomes of the experimental arm with the placebo arm, we can determine the true efficacy of the drug combination. Using normal saline as a placebo helps minimize bias and ensures the validity of the study results.

For the placebo comparator arm, we recommend administering normal saline in the same volume as the experimental arm. This should also be done via nasal cavity at 20:00 pm the day before surgery, the day of surgery, and the first day after surgery. This will allow us to have a consistent administration schedule for both arms and accurately assess the effects of the drug combination.

Certainly! Here are the full study arms:

1. Experimental: Dexmedetomidine and Esketamine
   - Participant Group/Arm: This arm includes patients who will receive a combination of Dexmedetomidine and Esketamine via nasal administration.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Dexmedetomidine 0.5 microgram/kg (300 microgram/ml) is administered via nasal cavity at 20:00 pm the day before surgery, the day of surgery, and the first day after surgery. Esketamine 0.2 mg/kg (25 mg/ml) is also administered via nasal cavity at the same time points.

2. Placebo Comparator: Normal saline
   - Participant Group/Arm: This arm includes patients who will receive normal saline via nasal administration as a control group.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Normal saline of the same volume as the experimental arm is administered via nasal cavity at 20:00 pm the day before surgery, the day of surgery, and the first day after surgery.

In an observational study conducted by Shapiro et al. in 2019, they found that higher post-wash TMSCs were significantly associated with a higher likelihood of pregnancy in patients undergoing insemination with thawed sperm from patients ≤40 years old with normal basic semen parameters .

Study Arm 3: Intrauterine insemination Patients with post-wash TMSC >3 x 10^6 undergo repeated inseminations on the same day and in the following days following the same procedure with intrauterine insemination on the subsequent days until the sperm counts fall below 3 x 10^6.

This study arm assesses the pregnancy rates of patients with a post-wash total motile sperm count below the recommended threshold of 3 x 10^6. By including this group, we can evaluate the impact of post-wash TMSC on pregnancy rates at levels below the reported optimum value for intrauterine insemination and identify whether the threshold can be lowered to achieve successful pregnancy.

This study arm is essential to assess the pregnancy rates of patients with a post-wash total motile sperm count below the recommended threshold of 3 x 10^6. By including this group, we can determine if there is a significant difference in pregnancy rates compared to the control group and the group with post-wash TMSC above the threshold. This arm will help determine the impact of lower post-wash TMSC on the success of intrauterine insemination.

   - Participant Group/Arm: This arm includes patients who will undergo early cessation of sedation and targeted temperature management (TTM) after a cardiac arrest with a favorable EEG pattern.

   - Participant Group/Arm: This arm consists of patients who will receive standard care, including sedation and targeted temperature management (TTM) for at least 24-48 hours post-cardiac arrest.
   - Intervention/Treatment: The control group will not undergo early cessation of sedation and TTM, as per standard care protocols.
   - Reasoning: This arm serves as a comparison group to evaluate the impact of early cessation of sedation and TTM in the experimental group. By having a control group receiving standard care, the study can determine if the experimental intervention leads to better outcomes compared to the standard approach. This arm helps establish the baseline for comparison and provides valuable insights into the potential benefits of early weaning from ICU treatment.

Study Arms:
1. Experimental: Subject glucometer measurement
   - Participant Group/Arm: Male or female patients with hypo-, eu- or hyperglycemia who have signed the written informed consent and are older than 18 years.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Diagnostic test using different blood glucose monitoring systems (BGM) and a reference method to measure blood glucose concentration. This arm is necessary to evaluate the system accuracy of the 14 blood glucose monitoring systems in comparison to a reference method. By including patients with different blood glucose levels, we can assess the performance of the systems across a range of glucose concentrations.

2. Control: Reference method measurement
   - Participant Group/Arm: Same participants as the Experimental arm.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Diagnostic test using a reference method to measure blood glucose concentration. This arm is necessary to establish a baseline for comparison with the results obtained from the different blood glucose monitoring systems. By using a standardized reference method, we can ensure consistency and accuracy in the evaluation of the system accuracy of the 14 blood glucose monitoring systems.

That's a valid point. Having a separate group of participants for the control arm would indeed be ideal to eliminate any potential bias. However, in this particular study, we are focusing on evaluating the system accuracy of the blood glucose monitoring systems within the same group of participants. This allows us to directly compare the performance of the systems in real-world conditions. If we were to use a separate group for the control arm, there could be variations in individual physiology and glucose levels that would introduce confounding factors. By using the same participants, we can minimize these variables and ensure a more accurate assessment of the system accuracy.

Certainly! Part A is the Escalation cohort and it aims to establish a safe and effective dose of the treatment. This is done by gradually increasing the amount of the treatment that participants receive until a recommended dose (known as the RD, Recommended Dose) is determined. Once the recommended dose has been determined, the trial can proceed to part B, which is the expansion cohort . This cohort will help validate the recommended dose from Part A by testing it against a control group, and demonstrating whether this dose combined with Pembrolizumab has anti-cancer effects that are greater or equivalent than Pembrolizumab alone.

Part B - Expansion will focus on determining the effectiveness of the combination of Tepotinib and Pembrolizumab. For this arm, we will enroll patients who only have a mutation in Exon 14 of MET (not both Exon 14 and Exon 20) and who also have not received prior therapy for advanced NSCLC. By enrolling these patients, we can assess the efficacy of the combination of Tepotinib and Pembrolizumab in patients with Exon 14 MET-mutated NSCLC without any prior treatment.

In Part A - Escalation, the Tepotinib will be administered orally once daily, in addition to intravenous Pembrolizumab, which will be administered every 3 weeks. The dose of Tepotinib will be gradually escalated, with an initial dose of 300 mg per day and a potential escalation up to doses of 500 mg, 750 mg, and 1000 mg per day.

In Part B - Expansion, patients with a confirmed MET exon 14 skipping mutation will receive Tepotinib daily for two weeks, followed by a three-week break. Pembrolizumab immunotherapy will then be given on a 21-day cycle. It is essential to note that the dosage of Tepotinib may be modified following interim analyses to maintain a manageable toxicity profile.

Meanwhile, the experimental arms test different dosages of the study product, Nicoventos, with the goal of determining the optimal dosage. Since the objective is to identify the most effective dosage, it is important to test several to identify any significant differences. In the first crossover phase, participants will be randomized to either the Experimental: Ampli-01, 3 mg nicotine pouch, Experimental: Ampli-01, 6 mg nicotine pouch, or the Active Comparator: ZYN Cool Mint Mini Dry, 6 mg nicotine/pouch group. After completion of the first phase, they will enter the second crossover phase and be assigned to a different test arm. This cross-over study design allows for each participant to serve as their own control, reducing the potential for inter-individual variability. By using a randomized crossover design, each study participant will complete all study arms, resulting in a complete “crossover” between study arms. This approach helps to minimize inter-subject variations and ensures adequate statistical power for each study arm.

From then on, they will receive QL1706 on day 1 of every 21-day cycle. Dose escalation will continue until the projected cohorts have been finished.

Absolutely! Let's start with the first study arm. The Experimental: QL1706H Part 1 (Dose escalation) arm is designed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of QL1706H in patients with advanced solid tumors. By administering QL1706H in sequential cohorts with escalating doses, we aim to determine the maximum tolerated dose and the recommended dose for further studies. The subcutaneous injection on day 1 followed by IV infusion on day 22 allows for the assessment of different routes of administration and dosing schedules. This arm is necessary to establish the safety profile and optimal dosing regimen of QL1706H.

The Experimental: QL1706H Part 2 (Dose Exploration) arm focuses on exploring the pharmacokinetic parameters of QL1706H at different administration intervals. By testing the drug at various time points, we aim to understand its exposure levels, distribution, metabolism, and elimination in the body. This arm is essential for optimizing the dosing schedule and frequency of QL1706H to achieve the desired therapeutic effect while minimizing potential side effects. It will provide valuable information for future studies and clinical use of QL1706H.

groundtruth: For the active comparator arm, I suggest the participant group/arm: "Femoral Triangle Block (FTB) + IPACK block." This arm includes patients who will receive the standard treatment of FTB along with the IPACK block, which is considered the standard of care. The FTB is a commonly used nerve block for knee replacement surgery, but it does not fully cover the skin component of the surgical incision. By adding the IPACK block, the sensory branches of the innervation posterior to the knee are blocked. This arm serves as the control group to compare the efficacy of the experimental PACS block in improving postoperative analgesia.

Certainly! Here are the detailed interventions/treatments for each study arm:

1. Experimental: Para-Sartorial Compartment (PACS) Block + Femoral Triangle Block (FTB) + IPACK block
- Procedure: Para-Sartorial Compartments (PACS) Block
  - This intervention was selected because it has the potential to optimize analgesia by skin coverage of the upper third of the surgical incision. The intervention will be performed as follows:
    - The intermediate femoral cutaneous nerve will be visualized at the supralateral level of the sartorius muscle, in a duplicature of the fascia lata.
    - The needle will be inserted at the same puncture site as for the femoral triangle block, with a latero-medial orientation in the plane (intracanalar compartment).
    - In addition to the injection performed in the femoral triangle, two injections of 5 mL of 0.5% ropivacaine + epi 1:400 000 will be performed in addition, below the sartorius muscle (subsartorial compartment) and above the sartorius muscle (suprasartorial compartment).
- Procedure: Femoral Triangle Block (FTB)
  - The high frequency linear ultrasound probe will be positioned midway between the superior edge of the patella and the anterosuperior iliac spine. It will then be moved to visualize the apex of the femoral triangle, confirmed by visualization of the sartorius muscle laterally and the long adductor medially.
  - The needle will be inserted with a latero-medial orientation in the plane.
  - The initial injection will be a single injection of 15 ml of 0.5% ropivacaine + epi 1:400 000 under the sartorius muscle, lateral to the femoral artery, at the level of the apex of the femoral triangle.
- Procedure: Infiltration between popliteal artery and capsule of the knee (IPACK) block
  - It will be performed in order to block the sensory branches of the innervation posterior to the knee with 15 ml of ropivacaine 0.3% + epi 1:400 000.

2. Active Comparator: Femoral Triangle Block (FTB) + IPACK block
- Procedure: Femoral Triangle Block (FTB)
  - The high frequency linear ultrasound probe will be positioned midway between the superior edge of the patella and the anterosuperior iliac spine. It will then be moved to visualize the apex of the femoral triangle, confirmed by visualization of the sartorius muscle laterally and the long adductor medially.
  - The needle will be inserted with a latero-medial orientation in the plane.
  - The initial injection will be a single injection of 15 ml of 0.5% ropivacaine + epi 1:400 000 under the sartorius muscle, lateral to the femoral artery, at the level of the apex of the femoral triangle.
- Procedure: Infiltration between popliteal artery and capsule of the knee (IPACK) block
  - It will be performed in order to block the sensory branches of the innervation posterior to the knee with 15 ml of ropivacaine 0.3% + epi 1:400 000.

Certainly. "Usual Care" is a common term used to describe the treatment that someone would receive if they were to enter healthcare as usual. It represents the current standard of care, which is the usual way of managing patients based on the existing protocols and guidelines. However, it is not necessarily the best practice available or the most optimal treatment approach. It is believed that including this arm in a clinical trial is necessary to provide a framework for understanding the effects of the experimental intervention being tested.

In the "Experimental: DIAPI" arm, the DIAPI algorithm will be used by the treating physician to manage the diabetes of patients during their peri-procedural period. The treating-physician may use the DIAPI as standalone or in addition to the recommendations provided by usual care. The treating-physician is not required to follow the recommendations made in the DIAPI algorithm. The DIAPI algorithm aims to guide healthcare-professional in their clinical practice by providing recommendations to patients based on the patient's peri-procedural conditions, such as current glycemic levels, scheduled intervention, and so on. So, the treating physician may choose to follow, partially follow, or not follow the recommendations of DIAPI. The DIAPI will also be updated continually by the clinical team. The proposed radiation schedule would commence with a single, initial course of stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT) of abdominopelvic metastases within two weeks of trial registration. The targeted dose to be delivered in this SBRT fraction would be equivalent to 48 or 50 Gray (Gy) biologically effective dose (BED), as calculated by the linear-quadratic model . Specifically, this dose would be divided into 5 or 7 biologically effective subdivisions (BEDsubs) (i.e., the total dose would be divided into five or seven equal 4- or 3-day intervals, respectively). Within 3-4 weeks of starting the SBRT, the participant would receive a CT-MRI simulation with a treatment planning CT scan in the radiotherapy treatment position to evaluate for a change in the abdominopelvic metastases. If a change in abdominopelvic metastases was observed, then a radiation schedule was adapted to account for changes in the target volume. The SBRT schedule would be repeated for three doses (12-15 Gy BED). Each SBRT dose would be delivered once per week for six to seven weeks to achieve 48-50 Gy BED. The simulation and treatment would be performed over three to four weeks per dose escalation (12-15 Gy BED/3-4 weeks). Certainly! In Treatment plan I (PSCA CAR T-cells), patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer would undergo leukapheresis to collect their T cells. These T cells would then be modified in the laboratory to express the PSCA-specific CAR receptor. The modified T cells, known as PSCA-CAR T cells, would be infused into the patients intravenously up to 3 times during the study. Additionally, patients would undergo lymphodepletion therapy, bone scans, CT scans, tumor biopsies, and collection of blood, stool, and urine samples.

In Treatment plan II (PSCA CAR T-cells, radiation), patients would undergo the same interventions as in Treatment plan I, but with the addition of external beam radiation therapy. The radiation therapy would be administered in 2 doses and is intended to further target and destroy cancer cells. The rest of the procedures, including leukapheresis, lymphodepletion, imaging studies, and sample collection, would be the same as in Treatment plan I.

Certainly! In the Experimental: Active tDCS arm, participants will undergo five in-person visits in Week 1 for the administration of active transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS). From Weeks 2 to 9, they will receive weekly active tDCS sessions preceding the scheduled yoga sessions. The tDCS sessions will involve the administration of a constant anodal current of 2 mA for 20 minutes, targeting the primary motor cortex contralateral to the most painful site. The yoga program will be led by a certified instructor and will consist of centring, warming up, yoga postures, and guided relaxation.

In the Sham Comparator: Sham tDCS arm, participants will attend five in-person visits in Week 1 for the administration of sham transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS). From Weeks 2 to 9, they will receive weekly sham tDCS sessions before the scheduled yoga sessions. The sham tDCS sessions will mimic the sensation of current without actual stimulation. Participants will also participate in the same yoga program led by a certified instructor.

There are a few different methods you can consider when allocating participants to study arms. One option is random assignment. This can be done using a random number generator or a random sequence generated with software or written on slips of paper. Alternatively, you can use block randomization, which involves a permuted block design, meaning that blocks of participants are randomly assigned to study arms. This can help ensure that each arm is evenly distributed throughout the study. You can also use stratified randomization, which involves pre-specifying groups of participants (such as age or gender groups) and ensuring that each group is evenly distributed across study arms. Finally, you may opt for non-random assignment, such as alternating allocation, which involves allocating participants to study arms in alphabetical order of participants' last name, date of birth, or medical record number. Just make sure you choose a method of assignment that is pre-specified in the study protocol and clearly documented so that the trial is replicable.

If the participants are aware of their study arm allocation, they may modify their behavior or perception of their condition. For example, participants assigned to the usual care arm may expend more effort during the treatment session if they are aware that they are receiving usual care. Conversely, participants assigned to a control group may exaggerate certain symptoms or show a placebo effect if they are aware that the intervention is inactive. Therefore, using a blind design where both the participants and the researcher are unaware of the allocation is recommended.

Here's a more detailed description of each study arm in the clinical trial: Group A (early oral feeding postoperative): Enrollment of patients aged 18 years and above who are presenting with perforated duodenal ulcers. After randomization, patients are offered clear fluids, including clear liquids and clear juice, after 6 hours postoperatively. Group B (traditional delayed oral feeding postoperative): Enrollment of patients aged 18 years and above who are presenting with perforated duodenal ulcers. After randomization, patients are advised to withhold oral intake for 72 hours postoperative, then commence from liquids only (i.e., tea, water, sodas, yogurt, pudding, and applesauce) for 48 hours and proceed to solids as tolerated until diet is tolerated. For both groups, all randomized patients will receive a perforated peptic repair. The surgical technique used involves abdominal exploration, closure of perforation with interrupted sutures using non-absorbable sutures (or polydioxanone), oversewing the serosal laceration, intraoperative lavage, and closed ileostomy. The wound is irrigated with bactera-cillin/metronidazole solution and closed in layers with sutures. Postoperative antibiotics will be administered and changed based on the culture sensitivity study. The primary outcome of this clinical trial is to document the association between early oral feeding and patient outcomes, which include hospital days, rehospitalization, 30-day readmission, complications, surgical site infection, and mortality. Secondary outcomes will include patient satisfaction with the type of oral feeding postoperatively, a 15-point pain scale, and a 15-point bowel function patient satisfaction questionnaire.

Group B is the control group with the traditional approach known as delayed oral feeding. In this group, the patients will receive nil per os (NPO), and oral feeding will be resumed 72 hours after perforated peptic ulcer repairs. This approach is more commonly used in practice, and this group serves as a benchmark for comparison with Group A. We will compare how the new approach in Group A compares with the traditional approach in Group B. Group B is designed to follow standard clinical guidelines and serve as a benchmark for the new intervention approach.

model_response: The TNB Identity Affirmation Condition is an essential part of the study. Here's a basic overview of the TNB Identity Affirmation arm: The participants will receive an instruction to write about their experiences with gender identity and gender expectations in a five-minute writing task. They will be instructed to write the answer to the following prompt based on a neutral and a relatable TNB scenario. First, they will be instructed to imagine that an acquaintance, an individual they regularly encounter but do not spend much time with, has recently begun transitioning and is very excited about it but also expresses anxiety or uncertainty about being misunderstood at work or encountering issues with others’ reactions, looks, names, and pronoun use. In this scenario, participants will be instructed to offer affirmation, words of advice, and encouragement, and share positive expectations for how their acquaintance’s transition may unfold. Subsequently, they will receive an additional scenario based on a relatable situation, in which the prompt will be adjusted to the participants’ background, and participants will be encouraged to reflect on their own experiences related to how they were perceived or treated on the basis of their TNB identity/identities, including name pronunciation, and other aspects of their appearance. They will be invited to write about a recent instance of such a treatment, what they wished they or others had said or done, and any positive takeaways from the situation or other ways they coped with it.

For the Strengthening Social Connection Study Arm, participants will compose two letters of gratitude to friends or family members who have provided meaningful support. This writing component is preceded by a prompt encouraging participants to reflect upon the ways others provide support and a prompt asking them to think of friends or family members who are meaningful to them but with whom they have not communicated recently. Following the composition of these gratitude letters, participants will be prompted to plan how they will share these letters with the individuals, and after sharing, they will write a post-letter response telling the study researcher about the sharing process, how the individuals reacted, and how they feel about it.

The control condition in our study will consist of expressive writing tasks on the four study days. These tasks will involve reflecting on their feelings or experiences with their relationships, day-to-day events, and feelings about their health in general. Each day, the participants will receive a different prompt for expressive writing. The prompts will be as follows:

Yes, exactly. The two experimental groups will engage in 15-minute computer-based task for four consecutive days, while the control group will complete a 15-minute computer-based writing task regarding events of the day on the first day of the intervention, and the second, third, and fourth days will be left blank. This is to ensure that the experimental groups do not feel different from the control group in terms of intervention duration. Moreover, participants will be given 2-3 minutes on each of the four days to write down their feelings at the beginning of their writing tasks to monitor their mood.
groundtruth: For the TNB Identity Affirmation (IA) Condition, participants will receive the same prompt for all four days of writing. This design, often used in expressive writing interventions, allows for deeper and continued reflection into specific thoughts and emotions. The prompt will involve reading a vignette that describes the experience and response of a young adult who experiences rejection from a close friend after a first disclosure of their gender identity. Participants will then be asked to write in response to three prompts: 1) identify expressions of internalized transphobia in the vignette character, 2) reflect on times the participant has experienced similar feelings, 3) identify thoughts and feelings that promote and support a positive and affirming identity in contrast to negative emotions and thoughts.

In the IA + Strengthening Social Connections (SSC) Condition, participants will complete the TNB Identity Affirmation intervention on the first three days, following the same prompts as the previous arm. On the fourth day, participants will be directed to compose a brief letter of gratitude to an individual to whom they have not previously expressed gratitude, and who has provided meaningful and affirming support to them as a TNB person. This additional component aims to further enhance social connections and gratitude, which are important factors in promoting well-being.

In the Control Condition, participants will engage in expressive writing about events of the day, without any specific prompts related to TNB identity or social connections. This neutral writing task will serve as a comparison to evaluate the specific impact of the TNB Identity Affirmation and Social Connection interventions on reducing internalized stigma and promoting well-being, compared to general expressive writing.

Exactly! You have successfully designed the study arms. These arms will allow us to assess the impact of TNB Identity Affirmation and Social Connection interventions on reducing stigma and promoting well-being in TNB individuals. Well done!

model_response: There are several ways to assign the patients into the treatment groups. One option is to use random assignment. We can use a random number generator to randomly assign each participant to one of the groups. Another option is to use cluster randomization, such as unit-level randomization, where the entire unit is assigned to a study arm, rather than individuals. This approach may reduce contamination between the study groups but may increase confounding and reduce statistical power. Lastly, stratified randomization may also be considered, where we stratify patients based on any known or suspected prognostic factors, such as critical illness, organ failure, and age. This method will allow us to balance the number of participants in each study group and to ensure that the groups are comparable.

Intervention Details:
- Ziv-Aflibercept is an investigational or experimental anti-cancer agent that inactivates vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) from functioning. - Cemiplimab is a human monoclonal anti-PD-1 antibody that works by blocking the programmed death-1 (PD-1) receptor on immune cells. This helps enhance the immune response against cancer cells.

The ACT treatment will consist of three 45 to 60-min weekly sessions to be delivered to the caregiver in an individual format via online videoconferencing application such as ZOOM or WhatsApp within 3 weeks. The ACT-CSP can be delivered via face-to-face upon request. Each session has specific content with pre-planned materials, mindfulness exercises, and metaphors. Psychological-based homework will be assigned at the end of each session. The components of the ACT process will be emphasized in the intervention program, which include perspective taking, self-as-context and defusion, identifying values, acceptance of present-moment experience, and committed action.
The participant group/arm for the control group should also be family caregivers of patients receiving palliative care.
In the control group, no specific intervention or treatment should be provided. The caregivers in this group will receive usual care provided at the participating site.

1. Experimental: Myofunctional Therapy Exercise
   - Participant Group/Arm: Seventeen patients who have been diagnosed by an Ear, Nose, and Throat specialist as having a risk of obstructive sleep apnea and showing pharyngeal muscle collapse in the velopharyngeal area/retropalatal.
   - Intervention/Treatment: These participants will perform myofunctional therapy exercises two times per day for 20 minutes every day for six weeks. All right, so the first arm is Native Bone. To create the Native Bone arm, the first step would be to identify the native bone in the antral area. This can be done by examining the imaging (e.g., CT or CBCT) taken prior to the extraction of the maxillary teeth, which should be no more than 6 months old. The next step would be to perform the sinus lift procedure in the antral area of the extraction socket of the maxillary teeth. This would involve elevating the sinus membrane and creating space for the placement of the bone graft material, which in your case will be autogenous bone (taken from edentulous sites). Afterwards, the bone graft material would be grafted in the antral area of the extraction socket of the maxillary teeth, and the sinus membrane would be repositioned over the bone graft material. Lastly, a plate would be secured in order to immobilize the site and allow optimal healing for 6 months.

The participant group/arm for the Regenerated Bone arm involves patients who have undergone the sinus lift procedure with autologous bone grafts without a barrier membrane in the antral area. The intervention is implants placed in an antral area with regenerated bone, and the analysis of ISQ values and its changes after 3 months of placing the implant in regenerated bone. This arm will utilize resonance frequency analysis to compare changes in ISQ values of implants placed in regenerated bone.

This arm will involve all participants receiving the intervention, which is physical activity. The intervention will primarily focus on exercises that can improve venous return and will consist of progressive walking training at moderate and high intensity. Participants will also receive guidance on physical activity. The training program is inspired by the WHO's recommendations for physical activity. Initially, there will be a 14-day introductory period where the goal is to achieve 30 minutes of moderate-intensity physical activity per day. After 14 days, the patient will receive physiotherapeutic guidance in physical activity and progress to the next period of 14 days, aiming for 2 sessions of 20 minutes of high-intensity physical activity per week. After one month of training, the patient will be guided on maintaining and possibly progressing physical activity. This arm will help us assess the value of early-initiated physiotherapy in improving outcomes for DVT patients.

No problem! As for Arm 1A, MDRT could start immediately after the SOC cytotoxic chemotherapy regimen is complete and then receive the recommended number of fractions of MDRT to reach the total dose. This is because SOC cytotoxic chemotherapy for mCRPC includes agents like Docetaxel which is a cytotoxic agent with a maximal effect on tumors lasting up to 4 to 6 weeks after administration. Following this maximal effect, there is tumor proliferation that causes clinical and biologic progression of the disease. It is this proliferation, not the decrease in tumor size, which is the cause of tumor progression . Therefore, the SOC cytotoxic chemotherapy regimen is followed by MDRT which can provide local control and palliation of symptoms. Treatment with MDRT can also offer the opportunity for prolonged clinical benefit and delay the time to disease progression . Hence, it is recommended that MDRT follows after the completion of SOC cytotoxic chemotherapy.

1. Experimental: VR-TrAC
   - Participant Group/Arm: Participants assigned to the VR-TrAC group will follow the Virtual Reality Training for Aggression.
   - Intervention/Treatment: The VR-TRAC group will undergo a 16-session training program focused on aggression control using virtual reality technology. The training is based on the Virtual Reality Aggression Prevention Training (VRAPT) protocol developed by Klein Tuente et al. The sessions are structured to target different stages of information processing related to aggressive behavior, including early and late stages. Participants will practice handling aggressive-inducing situations in virtual reality scenarios.
   - Reasoning: This study arm is essential to assess the effectiveness of the VR-TRAC intervention in reducing aggression among the prison-based population. The structured training program using virtual reality technology allows for a controlled and immersive environment to practice aggression control strategies. By comparing the outcomes of this group with the control group, researchers can evaluate the impact of VR-TRAC on aggression regulation.

2. Other: Care as Usual
   - Participant Group/Arm: Participants assigned to the Care as Usual group will receive standard care provided in the prison setting.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Care as Usual (CAU) in prison consists of treatments aimed at stabilizing psychological states, such as pharmacological treatment, supportive contact, or transfer to a Penitentiary Psychiatric Centre for necessary interventions.
   - Reasoning: This study arm serves as the control group for comparison with the VR-TRAC intervention group. By including a group that receives standard care practices in the prison environment, researchers can evaluate the additional benefits of the VR-TRAC program in reducing aggression beyond what is typically provided. This arm helps assess the incremental value of the VR-TRAC intervention in improving aggression control outcomes compared to standard care practices.

model_response: It is worth including separate arms specifically for mild and moderate hepatic impairment because liver function can affect drug pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics. Any alteration in these parameters can affect the therapeutic effect and safety profile of pharmaceuticals . If we don't take hepatic impairment into account, we might misestimate the optimal doses and dosing frequencies and also the risk of adverse effects in patients with normal hepatic function. For example, patients with mild or moderate hepatic impairment might be able to tolerate a higher dose than patients with severe hepatic impairment.

Including an arm for patients with severe hepatic impairment will help us understand if repotrectinib is safe to administer in these patients. It will also enable us to assess the impact of severe hepatic impairment on the pharmacokinetics of repotrectinib.

The baseline characteristics of patients with normal hepatic function, including parameters like serum albumin, bilirubin, and creatinine, can serve as references for the two groups with hepatic impairment. It will allow us to compare and assess potential differences between groups and better understand the impact of hepatic impairment on drug pharmacokinetics.

model_response: The standard care arm typically provides patients an opportunity to receive care based on the routine practices of the healthcare provider. It is intended to represent what is normally done for the condition of interest in real-world clinical settings. For older people with osteoporosis and osteopenia, the usual care commonly refers to physiotherapy or exercise therapy to improve their overall condition . The second arm is the active comparator arm, named "Late supplementary." Participants in this group will start receiving supplementary parenteral nutrition on postoperative day 5. Similar to the experimental arm, the intervention or treatment for this arm will also be the drug SmofKabiven. The dosage will be adjusted daily based on the participant's calorie intake. This arm serves as a comparison to the early supplementary group, allowing us to determine if delaying the start of parenteral nutrition until day 5 has any impact on outcomes. By having a delayed start group, we can evaluate the potential benefits of early intervention in the experimental arm.

The total dose will be 4.5 μg/kg per hour, infused over 12 hours, with the first dose given within 24 hours of the start of the symptom. The starting dose will be administered once, followed by 43 sequential doses. The treatment will be randomized.

Ghrelin is known to be responsible for the release of insulin and insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) [60, 61]. Insulin and IGF-1 play roles in ischemia and reperfusion in the brain after stroke, including promoting the shift from hyperglycolysis to hypoglycolysis [45–47], mediating the expression of IGF-1R, and enhancing cerebral vascular function, permeability, and angiogenesis [48, 49]. Our 50cc dose is based on the dosage and administration of the drugs that Ghrelin mimics. It is reasonable to assume that a large enough dose of Ghrelin would promote insulin release and IGF-1 expression.

For the control arm, we can label the participant group/arm as "Control: Standard care". This group will consist of patients who will receive standard care. The specific treatment will vary depending on the case and the guidelines in the local health authority.

We will use standard care as the control group to evaluate the benefit of Ghrelin beyond what is considered to be the standard treatment for stroke. This approach will help us to determine if the observed outcomes for Ghrelin users are solely attributable to Ghrelin.

The experimental arm is designed to test the hypothesis that Ghrelin can improve early recovery and long-term functional outcomes in stroke patients undergoing endovascular thrombectomy (EVT). By administering Ghrelin in the first six hours after stroke onset, we aim to assess its potential neuroprotective and neurorestorative effects in this population.

The participant group/arm for the control group will be labeled as "No Intervention: Standard care". This group will consist of patients who will receive standard care for stroke, including intravenous thrombolysis if indicated.

The control group will not receive Ghrelin treatment. Instead, they will be managed according to local practices for the treatment of stroke, including standard care and intravenous thrombolysis if indicated.

The control group serves as a comparison to assess the specific effects of Ghrelin on stroke recovery and functional outcomes. By including a control group, we can evaluate the impact of Ghrelin without confounding factors from other interventions, providing a clearer understanding of its potential benefits.

model_response: I'm glad I could assist you in designing the experimental arm of your study. Additionally, an important aspect to consider in research design is the validity of the study. There are four types of validity-construct, content, criterion, and statistical conclusion. Construct validity relates to whether a test assesses the intended concept. Content validity refers to whether the content of a test matches the topic or concept it is intended to measure. Criterion validity refers to the degree to which the results of the test may be generalized to individuals or situations different from those studied. Statistical conclusion validity refers to whether the statistical methods used are appropriate to draw the conclusions that were reached.

In the experimental arm, patients will receive Wilate® at a dose of 30-60 IU VWF:RCo/kg for the two anticipated heaviest days of bleeding every 24-48 hours within the first 4 days of menstruation, with the option for additional doses if needed. This arm aims to evaluate the efficacy of prophylactic Wilate® in reducing heavy menstrual bleeding in patients with VWD. The dosing schedule is designed to mimic real-world use and provide optimal benefit to patients.

In the placebo comparator arm, patients will receive intravenous placebo (normal saline) at the same approximate volume and frequency as the study drug. This arm is crucial in determining the true efficacy of the pdVWF:FVIII concentrate (Wilate®) compared to no treatment. By comparing outcomes between the experimental arm and the placebo arm, researchers can assess the specific impact of the active treatment on heavy menstrual bleeding in patients with VWD. Additionally, the placebo arm helps ensure blinding and reduces bias in the study results.

Finally, masking, or blinding, is the practice of concealing the intervention from patients, care providers, and usually outcome assessors, to minimize bias. Certainly. For the control arm, patients will receive conventional approaches to non-surgical periodontal therapy, which includes thorough supra- and subgingival scaling and root planning. This approach is a standard practice for the treatment of periodontitis and has been proven to help in reducing inflammation and in controlling the bacterial burden (2–4). For the experimental arm, patients will receive non-surgical periodontal therapy plus Emdogain®. Emdogain® is an enamel matrix derivative that contains proteins found in the ameloblasts of enamel forming teeth (5). It promotes the formation of new cementum, bone, and connective tissue attachment to the root surface, resulting in reduced pocket depths, improvements in clinical, and microbial outcomes. It is also thought to stimulate stem cells in the subgingival area to differentiate into macrophages, fibroblasts, and cementoblasts (5–7).

The experimental arm will receive a non-surgical periodontal treatment of the third and fourth quadrants with Emdogain® in both residual pockets. This arm is used to test the hypothesis that the addition of Emdogain® will improve the outcomes of non-surgical periodontal treatment.

Of course. The study includes six study groups: two quadrant control, two adjunctive therapy of Emdogain® (one arm used the standard dosage of 1.5 ml Emdogain® and the other employed 1.5 µg microspheres with 0.0005ml), and two adjunctive therapy of Emdogain® with laser irradiation.

We will also measure high-sensitive Troponin levels before and after the stress test. This arm aims to improve the diagnostic accuracy of CMR stress testing by adding exercise testing and biomarker measurement. It will be particularly beneficial for patients with balanced ischemia or severe CAD. What do you think?

   - Intervention/Treatment: Diagnostic Test: Exercise in combination with biomarkers and pharmacological stress CMR test. A bicycle ergometry combined with pharmacological stress test is performed. High-sensitive Troponin is taken before and after the stress test.

2. Active Comparator: Pharmacological stress test
   - Participant Group/Arm: Patients undergoing only pharmacological stress test with Regadenoson.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Diagnostic Test: Exercise in combination with biomarkers and pharmacological stress CMR test. A bicycle ergometry combined with pharmacological stress test is performed. High-sensitive Troponin is taken before and after the stress test.

groundtruth: Certainly! Let's start with the Experimental Treatment Group. In this group, patients will receive a combination chemotherapy regimen consisting of Onivyde, Leucovorin, 5-FU, and Tripegfilgrastim. The chemotherapy will be administered every two weeks. Tripegfilgrastim will be administered 24 hours after completing the 5-FU infusion to reduce the risk of severe neutropenia. The inclusion of premedication and specific chemotherapy drugs is essential for the standardization of treatment across all participants in this arm. This arm is necessary to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Tripegfilgrastim in reducing the risk of severe neutropenia in patients with unresectable pancreaticobiliary cancers.

In the No Intervention Control Group, patients will receive the same combination chemotherapy regimen as the Experimental Treatment Group, but without the administration of Tripegfilgrastim. In the event of febrile neutropenia, Tripegfilgrastim will be administered after stopping 5-FU. Chemotherapy will be paused until the patient recovers from neutropenia, and then restarted after recovery. This arm is important to compare the outcomes of patients receiving standard chemotherapy without Tripegfilgrastim to those receiving Tripegfilgrastim in the treatment group. This will help determine the effectiveness of Tripegfilgrastim in reducing the risk of severe neutropenia in this patient population.

groundtruth: The first study arm is the control group, where patients undergo surgical treatment for their chronic subdural hematomas but do not receive MMA embolization post-surgery. This arm will be referred to as Arm 1 - Surgery - No embolization.

The rationale for this arm is to compare the outcomes of patients who receive embolization (Arms 2) with those who do not. By having a control group, we can determine the effectiveness of MMA embolization in reducing recurrence and improving outcomes.

The second study arm involves patients who undergo surgical treatment for their chronic subdural hematomas and then receive MMA embolization within 72 hours post-surgery. This arm will be referred to as Arm 2 - Surgery - MMA embolization.

The purpose of this arm is to assess the efficacy of embolization after surgery in reducing recurrence and improving outcomes. By comparing the outcomes of patients in this arm with those in Arm 1, we can evaluate the impact of MMA embolization on the progression of hematomas.

The third study arm involves patients who are excluded from surgery either due to significant medical contraindications or because they refuse surgery. Instead, they will undergo MMA embolization only. This arm will be referred to as Arm 3 - No surgery - Embolization accepted.

This arm is important to assess the efficacy of embolization as a standalone treatment option for chronic subdural hematomas when surgery is not feasible. By comparing the outcomes of patients in this arm with those in Arm 4, we can determine the potential benefits of embolization in these specific cases.
The fourth study arm involves patients who are also excluded from surgery but refuse embolization as well. This arm will be referred to as Arm 4 - No surgery - Embolization not accepted.

This arm is necessary to evaluate the impact of not undergoing any intervention in cases where both surgery and embolization are not accepted. By having this arm, we can understand the natural progression of chronic subdural hematomas in patients who do not receive any treatment.

Certainly! Here are the full study arms:

1. No Intervention: Arm 1 - Surgery - No embolization (control)
Patients who undergo surgical treatment will be randomized into receiving embolization within 72 hours post-surgery (Arm 2) or no-embolization post-surgery (conventional management, Arm 1). Patients will be randomized at a rate of 2 MMA embolization to 1 conventional management.

2. Experimental: Arm 2 - Surgery - MMA embolization
Patients who undergo surgical treatment will be randomized into receiving embolization within 72 hours post-surgery (Arm 2) or no-embolization post-surgery (conventional management, Arm 1). Patients will be randomized at a rate of 2 MMA embolization to 1 conventional management. Intervention/Treatment: Radiation: MMA embolization (Middle meningeal artery embolization).

3. Active Comparator: Arm 3 - No surgery - Embolization accepted
Patients who are excluded from surgery due to significant medical contraindications or patients who refuse surgery will be considered for embolization only. Intervention/Treatment: Radiation: MMA embolization (Middle meningeal artery embolization).

4. No Intervention: Arm 4 - No surgery - Embolization not accepted
Patients who are excluded from surgery due to significant medical contraindications or patients who refuse surgery will be considered for embolization only. Intervention/Treatment: None.

We will name the study arms the active arm and the placebo arm. In the active arm, participants will receive real, non-invasive vagus nerve stimulation treatment, while in the placebo arm, participants will receive a placebo vagus nerve stimulation treatment.

For the Experimental arm, the participant group/arm will consist of participants who will receive non-invasive auricular vagus stimulation. The intervention/treatment involves using a non-invasive device to stimulate the auricular branch of the vagus nerve. Several experimental, preclinical and clinical studies have demonstrated that this type of electrical stimulation on the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (tVNS) can increase pain threshold and decrease hyperalgesia. One of the proposed mechanism underlying this effect of tVNS on pain is the inhibition of the sympathetic activity. In animal models of neuropathic pain, stimulating the auricular branch of the vagus nerve suppresses the expression of neuropeptide Y (which is involved in sympathetic activity), inflammatory pain mediators and proinflammatory cytokine release, thereby leading to a reduction in allodynia. Interestingly, both vagus nerve stimulation and electrical stimulation of the ear have been shown to decrease plasma norepinephrine, the neurotransmitter mostly responsible for the sympathetic activity, in conscious patients. Therefore, a speculated mechanism behind this phenomenon is the influence of electrical stimulation of the ear on the neurotransmitters of the neuroimmune system, namely, norepinephrine, and thereby inducing an anti-inflammatory effect. Interestingly, electrical ear stimulation by acupuncture (i.e., electroacupuncture), and by a device called Vital Stim, which has electrodes on the ears and nose (also called VNS Therapy or Nerivio), is being used in some medical centers for several conditions, including chronic pain, and shows positive results.

For the Placebo Comparator arm, the participant group/arm should consist of participants who will receive a placebo intervention. The intervention/treatment for this arm will involve using a non-invasive device that does not stimulate the vagus nerve.

The purpose of including a Placebo Comparator arm in this study is to enable us to evaluate the effect of the vagus nerve stimulation itself. By comparing the results of this arm to those of the Experimental arm, we can determine whether the changes observed are due to the stimulation of the vagus nerve, or to placebo effects.

Certainly! The full study arms are as follows: Experimental arm: Participants will receive both non-invasive auricular vagus stimulation, and aerobic exercise. The non-invasive device will consist of electrodes connected to a battery-powered device that delivers a low-level electrical pulse to the auricular branch of the vagus nerve in each outer ear canal. The device was described as “comfortable to wear and simple to use”. Placebo Comparator arm: Participants will receive both the placebo non-invasive device and aerobic exercise. However, instead of receiving non-invasive auricular vagus stimulation, participants in this arm will receive a placebo non-invasive vagus stimulation. The placebo device will not have any actual effect on the vagus nerve.

By comparing the results from the Experimental arm to the Placebo Comparator arm, we can determine whether any observed effects are due to the actual stimulation of the vagus nerve or other factors. This helps ensure the validity and reliability of the study results.

The components of a Maitland's mobilization are passive accessory mobilization (PAM), where the joint is manipulated through gentle stretching and oscillations of specific joints. The objective is to increase movement, reduce the pain and disability associated with OA. The other component is passive joint movement (PJM), which involves moving a joint through its available range of motion (ROM) without resistance. It helps to maintain the ROM while preventing muscle shortening and scar tissue formation. So, the experimental group will be receiving both PAM and PJM together with IFT? Is that correct?

For interferential therapy, a standardised protocol for the experimental group will be used. This protocol will apply continuous waves of 50-60Hz to prevent myofibril contraction, which can cause spasm and excessive energy being transferred to the soft tissues. The 50-60Hz wave band is also ideal for the treatment of edema, inflammation, and fibrosis. The duration of treatment will be 20 minutes per cycle and 1 cycle will be applied for 20 minutes. The electrodes will be placed at 2-5cm intervals, depending on the region being treated.

Mulligan's mobilization technique includes five basic components: manual contact, tissue stress, patient movement, stretching, and retraction. The aim of this technique is to produce movement, increase range of motion, and prevent further injury.

The basic parameters for interferential therapy in all study arms will be carrier frequency 4000Hz, waveform rectangular, sweep time 1 second rise and fall and 5-second stay, treatment duration 10 minutes, and sweep frequency 10 to 130 Hz. The current intensity is identical to the experimental group, which is adjusted until the subject reports feeling a strong tingling sensation without causing muscle contraction. Additionally, an aquatic gel should be applied before strapping the electropads over the treatment area for smooth electrical conduction.

Each participant's physician will invite them to complete a 48-hour ABPM, followed by cross-titration from their current antihypertensive regimen to the low BPV regimen. The low BPV regimen consists of Amlodipine and Indapamide as the primary medications. I would suggest starting patients on Amlodipine 5mg daily, with uptitration to 10mg daily to achieve a goal systolic blood pressure (SBP) of less than 130 mmHg. Indapamide should be added at 1.25mg daily and increased to 2.5mg daily if needed to meet the target SBP. Other antihypertensive medications should be discontinued as the SBP target is reached. Patients not meeting the target SBP on maximally tolerated Amlodipine and Indapamide will be suggested to have a long-acting angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE)/ angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) added to their therapy. After one week at the target SBP on the low-BPV regimen, patients will complete another 48-hour ABPM for evaluation of the change in BPV.

Patients not meeting the target SBP on maximally tolerated Amlodipine and Indapamide will be suggested to have a long-acting ACE/ARB added to their therapy. After one week at the target SBP on the low-BPV regimen, patients will complete another 48-hour ABPM for evaluation of the change in BPV.
