The Adaptive Behavior Assessment System (ABAS) is an instrument designed to assess adaptive functioning across multiple content areas. It provides a comprehensive assessment of functioning and need for services for individuals with developmental disabilities, including autism spectrum disorder and other intellectual and developmental disability categories. The authors of the Adaptive Behavior Assessment System (ABAS-3) have developed an adaptation of their assessment battery so that it can be used by individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities with a limited repertoire of verbal behaviors and who are capable of making some response to a core vocabulary containing 20 stimuli. The authors have identified a set of guidelines to aid in using the instrument with this population. The authors suggest that the adult version of the Adaptive Behavior Assessment System (ABAS-3) can be used with individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities who are limited in their verbal output when the test administration follows a structured, step-by-step protocol. This protocol involves the use of a core vocabulary containing only the stimuli relevant to the individual's evaluation and the use of augmentative strategies, including gestures, pictured instructions, facial expressions, and modeling.

model_response: Including a control group in your study can help to determine whether the observed changes in the experimental arms are due to the strength training itself or some other external factor. By providing a baseline for comparison, the control group allows you to assess whether there are any significant changes occurring in the absence of a specific intervention. Additionally, if you are planning to compare the results of this study to other studies that do include a control group, it is necessary to have one so that you can more fairly and effectively analyze and interpret the results. However, it ultimately depends on the specific objectives of your study and whether you feel that the data from the control group would provide valuable information and contribute to achieving those objectives.

In order to conduct a thorough assessment of the outcomes, it is crucial to collect data on the training load variables. It is necessary to determine if you will be using external or internal load monitoring devices. If you choose to use external load monitoring devices, please note that they tend to yield inaccurate results, especially for non-linear movements. It is recommended to use internal load monitoring devices that can collect data across multiple muscles simultaneously. This will allow you to capture the differences in internal loads between different muscles and movement cycles, providing valuable information for evaluating the effectiveness of strength training regimens. If it is possible, I would also recommend including a dynamic warm-up using a cycle ergometer at low intensity or bodyweight exercise prior to the resistance training protocols, as this will likely have an impact on the results of the study.

In this approach, each participant acts as their own control, as in the case of your design. The rationale for using a crossover design is to avoid potential confounding effects that are inherent in a pre- versus post- comparison, as participants in the same treatment group may respond differently to the intervention. The first participant will serve as their own control, and the final results can be interpreted without concerns that confounding factors such as differences in individual characteristics were responsible for the changes in the outcome.

Certainly! The 6-minute walk distance evaluation will provide valuable information on the patient's physical fitness and endurance, which is important for assessing their overall health status and potential post-operative outcomes. Activity monitoring through an Actigraph will help researchers understand the patient's daily activity levels and patterns, which can impact their recovery and long-term success following sleeve gastrectomy. Continuous glucose monitoring is crucial for monitoring glucose levels in patients with renal failure, as they are at higher risk for metabolic complications. Blood pressure monitoring is essential for patients with renal failure, as hypertension is a common comorbidity. Body composition scan will provide detailed information on the patient's body composition, including fat percentage, muscle mass, and visceral fat, which are important factors to consider in the context of sleeve gastrectomy and renal failure. Mixed meal testing will assess the patient's metabolic response to a standardized meal, providing insights into their nutritional status and potential post-operative dietary considerations. Quality of life assessment is crucial for evaluating the impact of sleeve gastrectomy on the patient's overall well-being and satisfaction with the procedure.

Great! Here is the study arm design for patients with renal failure undergoing sleeve gastrectomy:
- Participant Group/Arm: Renal Failure Sleeve Gastrectomy
- Intervention/Treatment: 
   - Diagnostic Test: 6 minutes walk distance
      - Subjects walk as far as possible for 6 minutes at a self-selected pace, and the total distance walked will be recorded
   - Behavioral: Activity Monitor
      - Subjects will wear an Actigraph on their wrist like a watch for up to 10 days at home to monitor activity.
   - Behavioral: Continuous Glucose Monitor
      - Subjects will collect glucose values in the fluid under their skin for up to 10 days at home.
   - Behavioral: Blood Pressure Monitoring
      - Subjects will monitor their blood pressure at home for 10 consecutive days 3 times a day
   - Diagnostic Test: Blood Pressure Monitoring
      - 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring
   - Diagnostic Test: Body Composition Scan
      - Measure of body fat percentage, skeletal muscle mass, body water, and visceral fat.
   - Diagnostic Test: Mixed meal testing
      - Subjects will consume 6 ml/kg body weight of Boost, up to a maximum of 360 ml, within 5 min
   - Diagnostic Test: Quality of Life
      - Subject will complete Quality of Life Questionnaire

The number of interviews conducted for qualitative research depends on several factors, including the study's objective, research question, data analysis method, and saturation level. Qualitative experts usually recommend the sample size to be small, typically between 10 and 15 participants . The goal for qualitative studies is to achieve theoretical saturation, which means that no new themes or patterns emerge from the data after interviews with subsequent participants. To attain saturation, it is generally recommended that an initial 5 to 50 participants will likely reveal the most relevant themes, while collecting data from an additional 5–10 individuals may help identify less common concepts, scenarios, or experiences, depending on the sample and data collection strategy . However, the exact number of interviews required can vary from person to person, depending on the characteristics of the population and the research question. By the time the 10th or 15th participant is interviewed, most key themes should be identified and refined.

In your study, the criteria for participation include patients with at least one canal-treated posterior tooth, multiple cusp loss, and at least one tooth wall loss. It is important to consider that tooth preparation for a crown can result in large amounts of tooth structure removal and may cause weakness in the tooth, especially in areas of remaining wall compromise. The removal of the pulp can leave the tooth susceptible to fracture, so it is usually recommended to make the preparation marginless (supragingival or nonsubgingival) to promote greater retention of existing tooth structure. Although supragingival margin is prefered because of the better ability in the removal of plaque around the final restoration without the use of surgical microscopes or magnifying glasses and easier access to the cervical margins of most tooth preparations, nonsubgingival margin can be prefered in deep cavities and tooth preparation. In these cases, subgingival cavities have already compromised the wall beneath the cavity itself, therefore, a subgingival margin elevation is needed for tooth strength . So, you can consider both supragingival and subgingival margins as two study arms, as well.

Resin-modified glass ionomer cements, commonly referred to as RMGI, are a type of light-cured materials that combine the properties of traditional glass ionomers such as fluoride release, radiopacity, and high bond strength, with those of resin-based composites, which are tooth-colored, adhesive, and non-corrosive to the oral environment (1). Glass ionomers are known for their biocompatibility and antibacterial properties, but they have been limited in use due to handling difficulties, low wear resistance, and low mechanical strength (2). The introduction of RMGI resolves some of the handling difficulties of conventional glass ionomers, while still providing high fluoride release and antimicrobial ability, along with improved mechanical properties, such as tensile strength.

Patients with histologic diagnosis other than adenocarcinoma, grade >2 neuropathy, or who are pregnant or nursing are also excluded. Additionally, individuals with uncontrolled active infection, known hypersensitivity to any of the components of the chemotherapeutic agents, receipt of concurrent investigational therapy, or previous anaphylactic reaction to human antibodies are excluded.
